title:
FIRST BOOK
Against the Thoughts of Gluttony

items.text: Against the thoughts that seek without the labor of fasting to cultivate the rational land
items.verse: Issachar has desired that which is good, resting between the inheritances. And because he saw that the resting place is good and the land is fertile, he subjected his shoulder to labor and became a farmer.

items.text: Against the thought that says to me, “Do not torment your soul with a lot of fasting that gains you nothing and does not purify your intellect”
items.verse: He made the bronze basin and its bronze stand from the mirrors of the women who fasted, who fasted by the doors of the tabernacle of witness, in the day in which he set it up.

items.text: Against the thoughts that stir up in us the desire to eat meat on a feast day and that advise us also to eat on account of the body’s illness
items.verse: And to the people say, “Purify yourselves for tomorrow, and you shall eat meat.... You shall not eat one day, not two, not five days, not ten days, and not twenty days. For a month of days you shall eat, until it [the meat] comes out of your nostrils. And it shall be nausea to you because you disobeyed the Lord, who is among you.”

items.text: Against the thought that seeks to be filled with food and drink and gives no heed to the harm that springs from filling the belly
items.verse: Having eaten and been filled, pay attention to yourself, lest you forget the Lord your God, who brought you out of the land of Egypt, out of the house of slavery.

items.text: Against the thought that says to me, “The command to fast is burdensome”
items.verse: The command that I give you this day is not burdensome, nor is it far from you.

items.text: Against the thought that desires to be filled with food and drink and supposes that nothing evil for the soul comes from them
items.verse: And Jacob ate and was filled, and the beloved one kicked; he grew fat and became thick and broad, and he abandoned the God who made him and departed from God his Savior.

items.text: Against the thought of gluttony that compels me to eat at the ninth hour
items.verse: God do so to me and more besides if I eat bread or anything else before the sun goes down.

items.text: Against the thought that suggests to me the loss of bread, oil, and other things that we need
items.verse: Thus says the Lord, “The jar of meal will not run out, and the jug of oil will not be diminished, until the day when the Lord gives rain upon the earth.”

items.text: Against the soul that wants to follow the path of the saints while being full of bread and water
items.verse: And the king of Israel said, “Take Michaias and send him to Semer the ruler of the city, and tell Joas the ruler’s son to put him in prison and to have him eat bread of affliction and water of affliction until I return in peace.”

items.text: Against the thought that says to us, “Look, the provisions that we have gathered are not sufficient both for us and for the brothers who come to us”
items.verse: For thus says the Lord, “They will eat and leave [some remaining].” And they ate and left [some remaining], according to the word of the Lord.

items.text: Against the thought that embitters me in the life of harsh poverty
items.verse: The Lord shepherds me, and I will lack nothing.

items.text: Against the thought that, even when there is no scarcity, gathers more bread than it needs, on the pretext of hospitality
items.verse: I was young, and I have indeed grown old. I have not seen a righteous person abandoned or his progeny seeking bread.

items.text: Against the thought that is attentive to food and clothing, but rejects attention to the truth
items.verse: I will declare my iniquity and I will attend to my sin.

items.text: Against the thoughts that advise us and say, “Do not live so severely; through fasting and constant labor you will wear out your weak body”
items.verse: And he labored forever, and he will live to the end, so that he will not see corruption when he sees sages dying.

items.text: Against the thought that says to me, “Do not wear yourself out so unsparingly and afflict your soul by keeping vigil”
items.verse: A broken and contrite heart God will not despise.

items.text: Against the thought that is anxious about food and drink and diligent about where it can get them
items.verse: Cast your anxiety upon the Lord, and he will sustain you.

items.text: Against the thought that suggests to me, “Keeping vigil does not benefit you at all; rather, it gathers many thoughts against you”
items.verse: I have watched and have become like a sparrow dwelling alone on a roof.

items.text: Against the thought that rebukes us because we abstain from oil and that does not remember that David did this and said
items.verse: My knees have become weak from fasting, and my flesh has been altered by [the lack of] oil.

items.text: Against the thoughts that hinder us from our way of life by instilling fear in us and saying, “A miserable death results from austere fasting”
items.verse: I will not die, but live, and I will recount the Lord’s works.

items.text: Against the thoughts that persuade me to desist a little from keeping frequent vigils and to give a little rest to the weak and miserable body
items.verse: I will not go into the tabernacle of my house; I will not get up upon the couch of my bed; I will not give sleep to my eyes nor drowsiness to my eyelids nor rest to my temples, until I find a place for the Lord, a tabernacle for the God of Jacob.

items.text: Against the thought that predicts to us that famine or great affliction is coming soon
items.verse: The Lord will not famish a righteous soul, but he will overthrow the life of the ungodly.

items.text: Against the thought that suggests to me desire for wine on the pretext that the liver and spleen are harmed by water
items.verse: He who takes pleasure in banquets of wine will leave dishonor in his strongholds.

items.text: Against the thought that is bound by concern about the desire for foods and rejects concern about achievements in virtue
items.verse: With everyone who is careful there is abundance, but the pleasure-taking and the indolent will be in want.

items.text: Against the thought that weeps over simple foods and dry bread
items.verse: A morsel with pleasure in peace is better than a house full of many good things and unjust sacrifices with strife.

items.text: Against the thoughts that persuade us on a feast day to show a little mercy to our body by offering it a few delicacies
items.verse: Delight does not suit a fool, [nor is it proper] if a servant begins to rule with arrogance.

items.text: Against the thought that, in the absence of serious illness, coaxes us to drink wine and prophesies to us about pain in the stomach and the entire digestive system
items.verse: Wine is an intemperate thing, and drunkenness leads to insolence, and anyone who is tangled up in it is no sage.

items.text: Against the thought that seizes our intellect so that we bind ourselves to our fast and our ascetic practice by our oaths, something that is foreign to the monastic way of life
items.verse: It is a trap for a man hastily to consecrate some of his possessions, for regret comes after the making of the vow.

items.text: Against the thought that hinders us by suggesting that we not give from our bread to those in need and by saying to me, “That person can [find mercy] anywhere, but we cannot approach any stranger’s door”
items.verse: The one who shows mercy will himself be supported, for he gave to the poor from his own bread.

items.text: Against the thoughts that on a feast day gently approach us and say to us that we might just once in a long stretch of time taste meat and wine
items.verse: Do not be a wine-drinker, and do not stay long at feasts and sales of meat, for every drunkard and customer of prostitutes will be poor, and every sluggard will clothe himself in tattered and ragged garments.

items.text: Against the thought that recalls delicacies of the past and remembers pleasant wines and the cups that we used to hold in our hands when we would recline at table and drink
items.verse: For if you set your eyes on bowls and cups, you later will go more naked than a pestle. At the end he stretches himself out like someone struck by a snake and through whom venom is diffused as by a horned serpent.

items.text: Against the thoughts that entice us to fill our belly with bread and water
items.verse: Do not give the bed of a righteous man to a sinner, and do not go astray in satiety of the couch.

items.text: Against the thoughts that we have in opposition to the shame in which we respect the fathers when they persuade us to relax the fast and to eat vegetables during a feast
items.verse: For there is a shame that brings sin, and a shame that is glory and grace.

items.text: Against the demon that persuades me through its flattery and says to me with promises, “You will no longer suffer any harm from food and drink because your body is weak and dry from prolonged fasting”
items.verse: A weeping enemy promises everything with his lips, but in his heart he contrives deceits.

items.text: Against the thought that shows me God’s commandments as if they were difficult and tells me that they bring many difficulties and miseries upon the body and soul
items.verse: The wounds of a friend are more trustworthy than the spontaneous kisses of an enemy.

items.text: Against the thought that asks for a little wine in the absence of illness and says to me, “Look, it was for the sake of human beings that wine was created”
items.verse: He has made all things beautiful in his season.

items.text: Against the thought that reminds me of past feasting and drinking and wants [to return to] this custom
items.verse: It is better to go into a house of mourning than to go into a house of drinking.

items.text: Against the vain thought that persuades us to extend our discipline beyond what is appropriate by putting sackcloth on our loins, setting out for the desert, living continuously under the sky, and tending wild plants; and that advises us as well to flee from the sight of human beings who comfort us and who are comforted by us
items.verse: Do not be very righteous or especially wise, lest you be deceived.

items.text: Against the thoughts that remind us of past feasts and show us the difficulty that has occurred
items.verse: If we have received good things from the Lord’s hand, shall we not endure evil things?

items.text: Against the soul’s thought that travels to its corporeal kinfolk and finds a table filled with all kinds of foods
items.verse: Get up and leave, for this is not your place of rest because of uncleanness.

items.text: Against the thought of gluttony that on feast days enumerates for me many people reclining at the finest table, exulting and rejoicing
items.verse: But I will exult in the Lord and rejoice in God my Savior.

items.text: Against the thoughts that remind us of pleasures and of a table that has been filled with all good things and praise these things as better than the monastic life
items.verse: Woe to those who call evil good and good evil, who make darkness light and light darkness, who make bitter sweet and sweet bitter.

items.text: Against the soul’s thought that has become tired and weary of the hunger that comes with little bread and scant water
items.verse: And the Lord will give you bread of affliction and scant water, and yet those who deceive you will no longer come near you; for your eyes will see those who deceive you, and your ears will hear the words of those who went after you to lead you astray.

items.text: To the Lord concerning the infirmity of my body, which has been weakened by much fasting and diminished by an austere discipline, and concerning my soul, which is filled with evil thoughts of fornication
items.verse: Lord, remember me and visit me, and vindicate me from before those who persecute me without delay. Know how I have received reproach for your sake from those who set at naught your words.

items.text: To the Lord concerning the demon that chills the stomach and all the sinews of the body, and casts great weakness into the body as if from hunger and prolonged illness
items.verse: See, Lord, that I am afflicted, that my belly is troubled and my heart is turned within me.

items.text: Against the soul that is not satisfied with bread for food and water for drink, but wants vegetables along with these, and does not remember the affliction of the seeds that Daniel and his companions ate
items.verse: Then Daniel said to Amelsad, whom the chief eunuch had set over Daniel, Hananiah, Mishael, and Azariah, “Test your children for ten days, and give us seeds, and let us eat, and let us drink water. And let our appearance be seen by you and the appearance of the children that eat at the king’s table, and deal with your servants as you see.” And he listened to them and tested them for ten days. And at the end of the ten days, their appearance looked better and stronger in flesh than the children who ate at the king’s table. And Amelsad took away their supper and the wine of their drink, and he gave them seeds.

items.text: Against the soul that at the time of attack wants to find strong armor
items.verse: Then Jesus was led up by the Spirit into the wilderness to be tempted by the devil. He fasted forty days and forty nights, and afterwards he was famished.

items.text: Against the thoughts that are anxious about food and clothing on the pretexts of hospitality, illnesses, and prolonged miseries of the body
items.verse: Do not worry about your life, what you will eat or what you will drink, or about your body, what you will wear. Is not life more than food, and the body more than clothing?

items.text: Against the soul that is bound by gluttony and supposes that by refreshing the body with delicacies it travels the road of life
items.verse: For the gate is narrow and the road is hard that leads to life, and there are few who take it.

items.text: Against the thought that hinders us from giving to the needy from our food and clothing on the pretexts, “The provisions are not enough for both us and them” or “There is someone weaker or in greater need than this person, and we should give to that person rather than this one, for this one is lazy and wants to eat and be clothed without working”
items.verse: Whoever has two coats must share with anyone who has none; and whoever has food must do likewise.

items.text: Against the soul that loves the desires and collects food and clothing for itself alone
items.verse: All who believed were together and had all things in common; they would sell their possessions and goods and distribute the proceeds to all, as any had need.

items.text: Against the soul that grows weary in the affliction that comes upon it from restriction of bread and water
items.verse: It is through many afflictions that we must enter the kingdom of God.

items.text: Against the thoughts that persuade us to show a little care for our body by eating and drinking
items.verse: Make no provision for the flesh, to gratify its desires.

items.text: Against the thoughts that entice us to be comforted with a little treat of vegetables
items.verse: The weak eat vegetables.

items.text: Against the thought that at harvest time casts into us the desire for fruits
items.verse: Athletes exercise self-control in all things; they do it to receive a perishable wreath, but we an imperishable one.

items.text: Against the thoughts that arise in us because of great need and that gradually relax the soul’s vigor
items.verse: We are afflicted in every way, but not crushed; perplexed, but not driven to despair; persecuted, but not forsaken; struck down, but not destroyed; always carrying in the body the death of Jesus, so that the life of Jesus may also be made visible in our bodies.

items.text: Against the thought that depicts before our eyes a disease of the stomach, liver, and spleen, and a blowing that exceeds [the capacity of ] the navel
items.verse: So we do not lose heart. Even though our outer nature is wasting away, our inner nature is being renewed day by day.

items.text: Against the thoughts that arise in us as our entire body becomes gradually corrupted
items.verse: For we know that if the earthly tent we live in is destroyed, we have a building from God, a house not made with hands, eternal in the heavens.

items.text: Against the thought that arouses compassion in us, persuades us to give to the poor, and afterward makes us sad and annoyed about what we gave
items.verse: Not reluctantly or under compulsion, for God loves a cheerful giver, and the one who has compassion on the poor will be supported.

items.text: Against the thought that depicts in us severe weakness from diseases that are about to arise in us from fasting, and that persuades us to eat a little cooked food
items.verse: For whenever I am weak, then I am strong.

items.text: Against the thought that wants to be filled with wine on a feast day
items.verse: Do not get drunk with wine, for that is debauchery; but be filled with the Spirit, as you sing psalms and hymns and spiritual songs among yourselves, singing and making melody to the Lord in your hearts.

items.text: Against the thoughts that make our soul neither want to gather provisions through manual labor nor be persuaded to receive something from its family because they are poor and reside at a great distance, but rather advise it to fill its need from others
items.verse: The Lord is near. Do not worry about anything, but in everything by prayer and supplication with thanksgiving let your requests be made known to God.

items.text: Against the thought that predicts to me hunger and loss of bread and suggests to me the disgrace of receiving a favor from others
items.verse: In any and all circumstances I have learned the secret of being well fed and of going hungry, of having plenty and of being in need. I can do all things through him who strengthens me.

items.text: Against the thought that hinders us from working with our hands and persuades us to expect to receive what we need from others
items.verse: But we urge you, brothers, to do so more and more, to aspire to live quietly, to mind your own affairs, and to work with your hands, as we directed you, so that you may behave properly toward outsiders and be dependent on no one.

items.text: Against the thinking that hinders us from working with our hands and compels us to eat bread and to fill ourselves
items.verse: Anyone unwilling to work should not eat.

items.text: Against the thought that says that the monastic discipline is difficult and extremely burdensome, that through affliction it cruelly lays waste to our body, and that it does not profit the soul
items.verse: Now, discipline always seems painful rather than pleasant at the time, but later it yields the peaceful fruit of righteousness to those who have been trained by it.

items.text: Against the thinking that is diligent about food and neglects compassion for the needy
items.verse: Do not neglect to do good and to share what you have, for such sacrifices are pleasing to God.

items.text: Against the thought that, in the absence of pain in the stomach and severe illnesses, advises us to drink wine by suggesting to us the blessed Apostle’s direction when in his letter he commanded Timothy on this point
items.verse: Keep yourself pure. No longer drink only water, but take a little wine for the sake of your stomach and your frequent ailments.

items.text: Against the thoughts that turn us back toward the world and its commandments
items.verse: Do you not know that friendship with the world is enmity with God? Therefore, whoever wishes to be a friend of the world becomes an enemy of God.

items.text: Against the thought that supposes that the commandment to fast is burdensome
items.verse: And his commandments are not burdensome, for whatever is born of God conquers the world. And this is the victory that conquers the world, our faith.

title:
SECOND BOOK
Against the Thoughts of Fornication

items.text: Against the thought of fornication that depicts in my intellect a married woman
items.verse: You shall not covet your neighbor’s wife.

items.text: Against the thought of sadness that arises in us due to the many temptations of fornication that come upon us and cut off our hope by saying to us, “What beautiful thing do you expect after all this labor?”
items.verse: If you indeed listen to my voice and do all the things that I will say to you, I will be an enemy to your enemies and an adversary to your adversaries. For my angel will go as your leader and will bring you to the Amorite, and Hittite, and Perizzite, and Canaanite, and Gergesite, and Hivite, and Jebusite, and I will destroy them.

items.text: Against the thought that supposes that in a single hour the evil thoughts of fornication will flee from it
items.verse: I will not cast them out in one year, lest the land become desolate and the beasts of the land multiply against you. Gradually I will cast them out from before you, until you have increased and will inherit the land.

items.text: Against the thought that comes from fornication and says, “Youth can never cease from the desires of fornication and offer to God thoughts purified of it”
items.verse: Everyone who is registered from age twenty and older shall offer the sacrifice to the Lord.

items.text: Against the thought of fornication that says, “Youth is neither guilty nor culpable if it fornicates or if it gladly receives unclean thoughts”
items.verse: And the Lord said to Moses, “If anyone has sinned against me, I will wipe them out of my book.”

items.text: Against the intellect that does not make a vigilant effort to preserve itself from the fornication that is established within it, but rather speaks and performs wickedness with a woman that is depicted before its eyes
items.verse: And hear, Israel, and observe so as to do them, so that it may be well with you and so that you may be greatly multiplied, just as the Lord God of your fathers said that he would give you a land flowing with milk and honey.

items.text: Against the thought that seeks, through filthy desire, to approach the demon of fornication
items.verse: You shall fear the Lord your God, and serve only him, and cleave to him, and swear by his name.

items.text: Against the soul that day and night is harassed by thoughts of fornication, losing hope that it will gain victory over them
items.verse: But if you should say in your thinking, “This nation is greater than I: how will I be able to destroy them?” you shall not fear them. Remember what the Lord your God did to Pharaoh and all the Egyptians.

items.text: Against the thought of the soul that is oppressed by thoughts of fornication, which divide the evil passion of fornication into diverse images, collect impure thoughts, put them in rotation, [then] cleave to one of these enslaving thoughts and make it persist upon the weak soul
items.verse: And you will know today that the Lord your God will advance before you. He is a consuming fire. He will destroy them and turn them back from before you, and he will destroy them quickly, just as the Lord said to you.

items.text: Against the thoughts that turn quickly to foods whenever the spirit of fornication, playing with them, gives them a little respite and so they suppose that they have reached the frontier of chastity
items.verse: You shall not do all that we do here today, each person [doing] what is pleasing to him. For up to now you have not reached the rest and inheritance that the Lord your God gives you.

items.text: Against the soul that is frightened and shaken by the demon that touches its members; those who have been tempted by this demon consider what has been said
items.verse: Your helper will hold his shield over you, and his sword is your boast; and your enemies will lie to you, and you will tread upon their neck.

items.text: Against the soul that due to sadness falls into listlessness and so is no longer able to endure the filthy thoughts that defile its prayer
items.verse: Rise up, for this is the day on which the Lord has delivered Sisera into your hand; for the Lord will advance before you.

items.text: Against the intellect that is contending with thoughts of fornication, but does not want to shake them off of it completely and does not recognize the fetter of sin and the anxiety of evils
items.verse: And Delilah said, “The Philistines are upon you, Samson!” And he woke up from his sleep and said, “I will go out just like every other time, and I will shake them off.” And he did not know that the Lord had departed from him. And the Philistines seized him, cut out his eyes, brought him down to Gaza, and bound him with fetters of brass; and he ground at the mill in the prison house.

items.text: To the angel of the Lord that suddenly appeared in my intellect, cooled the thought of fornication, and drove out from it [my intellect] all the thoughts that besieged it
items.verse: My heart is established in the Lord; my horn is exalted in my God; my mouth is enlarged over my enemies; I have rejoiced in your salvation.

items.text: Against the filthy demon of fornication that appeared to me at night in an obscene vision in the form of a woman, but which could not compel my soul with its filthy desires
items.verse: The bow of the mighty ones has become weak, and the weak ones have girded themselves with strength. Those who were full of bread have been brought low, and the hungry have forsaken the land.

items.text: Against the soul that does not want to escape unclean desire but persists in the thought of Nahash the Ammonite, which [Nahash] is translated “snake”
items.verse: And all the men of Jabesh said to Nahash the Ammonite, “Make a covenant with us, and we will serve you.” And Nahash the Ammonite said to them, “On these terms I will make a covenant with you, that I should put out all your right eyes and I will lay a reproach upon Israel.”

items.text: Against the demon of fornication that wants to spoil and defile my chastity through thoughts
items.verse: My God forbid that I should give you the inheritance of my fathers.

items.text: Against the soul that supposes that it is tempted by the demon of fornication beyond its power
items.verse: Then the land began to be subject to tribute to give silver at the command of Pharaoh, and each person according to his ability paid the silver and gold required by the people of the land to give to Pharaoh Neco.

items.text: To the Lord concerning the thoughts of fornication that show us abominable visions at night
items.verse: And I said, “Lord, I am too ashamed and confounded, my God, to lift my face to you, for our transgressions have multiplied upon our head, and our trespasses have increased even to heaven. From the days of our fathers we have been in a trespass until this day.”

items.text: Against the soul that after valiant combats with thoughts of fornication has acquired chastity and purity
items.verse: The land into that you enter to inherit is disturbed by the removal of the peoples of the nations for their abominations, with which they filled it from mouth to mouth with their acts of uncleanness.

items.text: To the Lord concerning the multitude of unclean thoughts that trouble and afflict us and attract our intellect to diverse faces
items.verse: Lord, why are they who afflict me so numerous? Many rise up against me. Many say to my soul, “There is no salvation for him in his God.” But you, Lord, are my helper, my glory, and the one who lifts up my head.

items.text: Against the soul that does not know that the intensity of irascibility opposes the thought of fornication, because irascibility comes from fire by nature, but unclean thoughts are born of water
items.verse: Be angry, and do not sin. Speak in your hearts, and feel compunction upon your beds.

items.text: Against the unclean thoughts that persist in us and frequently depict in us obscene images and that bind our intellect with passions of desire in our dishonorable members
items.verse: Depart from me, all your workers of iniquity, for the Lord has heard the sound of my weeping; the Lord has heard my petition; the Lord has accepted my prayer.

items.text: To the Lord concerning the demon of fornication that, when it cannot humiliate us through the desire of our body, then shows us in our intellect a monk performing the obscene sin of fornication
items.verse: The swords of the enemy have failed utterly, and you have destroyed cities. Their memory has been destroyed with a noise, but the Lord endures forever.

items.text: To the Lord concerning the filthy demon of fornication that openly approaches the thighs of those who endeavor to depart from it, suddenly seizing the intellect with a madness that alters the soul through a multitude of powerful thoughts of fornication—it is very useful when we are tempted by this demon to jump up at once and to use our cell for frequent and brisk walks—let the one who is able to understand, understand
items.verse: Light up my eyes, lest I sleep unto death, lest at any time my enemy say, “I have prevailed against him.”

items.text: Against the soul that supposes that the thoughts of fornication are more powerful than God’s commandments, which were given to us for the extirpation of this passion
items.verse: I will beat them like the dust before the wind, and I will grind them like the mud of the streets.

items.text: To the Lord concerning the demon that suddenly fell upon the body, but could not conquer the intellect through the unclean thoughts that attacked it
items.verse: You have turned my sorrow into dance for me; you have ripped off my sackcloth and have girded me with gladness, so that my glory may sing praise to you and I may not be pierced.

items.text: Against the thought that says to me, “The demon of fornication will put you to shame if you stand up to it in battle”
items.verse: Let those who seek my soul be put to shame and confounded; let those who devise evils against me be turned back and put to shame.

items.text: Against the thought that threatens me, “Another demon of fornication—weightier, bolder, and stronger than the first—is being sent to you, one that will easily compel your soul and bring it to the sin that is accomplished in deeds”
items.verse: Let them be as dust before the wind, with an angel of the Lord afflicting them. Let their way be dark and slippery, with an angel of the Lord persecuting them.

items.text: Against the soul that, when it is being harassed by thoughts of fornication, rejects sackcloth and does not remember that David did this very thing for our instruction when he said
items.verse: But as for me, when they troubled me, I put on sackcloth and humbled my soul with fasting.

items.text: Against the soul that is saddened because the filthy thoughts of fornication have persisted in it and that does not expect victory over them because it sees that one of the filthy images is fixed in its intellect and continually harasses it
items.verse: Yet a little while, and the sinner will not exist, and you will seek his place, and you will not find it.

items.text: Against the demon of fornication that imitates the form of a beautiful naked woman, luxurious in her gait, her entire body obscenely dissipated, [a woman] who seizes the intellect of many persons and makes them forget the better things
items.verse: Therefore, may God destroy you forever; may he pluck you up and remove you from your dwelling and your root from the land of the living.

items.text: Against the thought that prophesies to me that I will fall away from chastity and be put to shame before human beings
items.verse: Let all who hate Zion be put to shame and turned back. Let them be like the grass of the housetops, which withers before it is plucked up.

items.text: Against the demon of fornication that in a dream at night drew me into filthy behavior and then during the day through thoughts taunted us and laughed at us
items.verse: Therefore, I too will laugh at your destruction, and I will rejoice over you when ruin comes upon you, and when fear suddenly comes upon you and your overthrow comes like a tempest.

items.text: Against the thoughts that compel us to linger in conversation with a married woman on the pretext that she has visited us frequently or that she will benefit spiritually from us
items.verse: Do not be long with someone else’s woman.

items.text: Against the intellect in which is depicted the form of a beautiful woman and that wants to speak with her earnestly or to do something evil that would not be proper, as the holy John, the prophet of Thebes,recounted to us
items.verse: Let not the desire for beauty conquer you; do not be ensnared by your eyes nor captured by her eyelids. For the price of a harlot is as much as one loaf of bread.

items.text: Against the thought that persuades me that we will not be harmed by the sight of a harlot
items.verse: Can anyone bind fire in his bosom and not burn his clothes? Or can anyone walk on coals of fire and not burn his feet? So too the one who goes into a married woman will not be held guiltless.

items.text: Against the soul that does not know the reason for temptations and also does not understand that the demon of fornication, whenever it is conquered and departs from us, leaves within us perfect chastity
items.verse: Just as silver and gold are tested in the furnace, so too elect hearts by God.

items.text: Against the unclean thought that entices us and turns us back to that sin for which we have many times repented before the Lord
items.verse: Just as a dog, when it returns to its own vomit, becomes abominable, so is a fool who returns in his wickedness to his own sin.

items.text: Against the thought that reminds us of the house in which we gave many fruits to Satan
items.verse: The heart of the wise is in the house of mourning, but the heart of the fool is in the house of mirth.

items.text: Against the soul that is encountering temptations of filthy thoughts and does not want to drive them away with hunger, thirst, keeping vigil, and prayer
items.verse: If the spirit of the ruler rises up against you, do not leave your place, for soothing will put an end to great sins.

items.text: To the holy angels concerning the unclean thoughts that have persisted in the soul
items.verse: Do not look at me, for I am dark, for the sun has looked unfavorably upon me.

items.text: Against the soul that supposes that it is unnatural for it to keep the intellect keen and not to fornicate in its thinking
items.verse: For Job said, “Lest my sons have ever devised evil things against God in their thinking.”

items.text: Against the soul that is tested by the demon of fornication with a great unspeakable temptation and marvels at the stupendous temptation to such an extent that this demon is neither put to shame nor feared
items.verse: Is not the life of a human being upon the earth a state of trial and his existence like that of a hired hand by the day?

items.text: Against the thought that prophesies to me that demons of fornication are coming and will touch our members and set them on fire
items.verse: In the day darkness will come upon them, and let them grope at noon as if it were night.

items.text: Against the demon of fornication that compelled Israel to gather straw and reeds instead of grains of wheat
items.verse: Far be it from me to sin before the Lord and to disturb righteousness before the Almighty. Rather, he pays back the human being according to what each of them does.

items.text: For the soul that does not know from where these burning thoughts are sent against us
items.verse: Out of his [Leviathan’s] mouth proceed, as it were, burning lamps.

items.text: Against the thought of fornication that says to me, “I am neither diminished nor destroyed by hunger, thirst, or strenuous fasting”
items.verse: But he will destroy your seed with hunger, and he will destroy your remnant.

items.text: Against the demon that advised me in my intellect that I should marry a woman and become the father of sons and so not resist fornicating thoughts with hunger and thirst
items.verse: For the fool will say foolish things, and his heart will think up vain things, in order to perform lawless acts and to speak error against the Lord, in order to scatter hungry souls and to make thirsty souls empty.

items.text: To the Lord concerning the demons of fornication that take for themselves pretexts from the Scriptures and from the topics that are written in them
items.verse: Lord, who proves righteous deeds and understands guts and hearts, let me see your vengeance upon them, for to you I have revealed my defenses.

items.text: To the Lord concerning the thoughts of fornication that have persisted in me
items.verse: See, Lord, my humiliation, for the enemy has become magnified.

items.text: To the Lord concerning the demon that at night stirred up an accursed thought against my soul and distorted all the features of the face
items.verse: Look, Lord, and see that she has become dishonored.

items.text: Against the soul that has fallen into obscene visions of the night
items.verse: Arise, rejoice in the night at the beginning of your watch; pour out your heart like water before the face of the Lord.

items.text: To the Lord concerning the demon of fornication that, through the passion of desire, imprints in my intellect the vision of an obscene form
items.verse: I called upon your name, Lord, from the lowest dungeon. You heard my voice: do not close your ears to my supplication. You drew near to help me; on the day when I called upon you, you said, “Do not be afraid.”

items.text: Against the demon of fornication that, whenever its thoughts ceased, began to explore and touch the body’s members— those who have been tempted by this demon will understand what I am saying—those who contend with it should at the time of the attack spend most of the night and day walking in the cell and praying and should catch [only] a little sleep while sitting, and they should wear rough sackcloth and avoid being filled with bread and water; let those who struggle in this contest understand that when by God’s power they defeat this demon, they will acquire chastity and not be corrupted
items.verse: And they will drive you forth from human beings, and your dwelling will be with wild beasts, and they will feed you with grass like an ox, and you will lodge under the dew of heaven, and seven times will pass over you, until you know that the Most High rules the kingdom of human beings and will give it to whomever he wishes.

items.text: Against the intellect that, because of images of men and womenthat are established in its thinking, is eager to commit a sin
items.verse: Everyone who looks at a woman with lust has already committed adultery with her in his heart.

items.text: Against the soul that is tempted by foul thoughts of fornication and does not want to keep vigil and pray
items.verse: Stay awake and pray that you may not come into temptation.

items.text: Against the thoughts that sometimes lead us to the markets and at other times compel us to hang around outside the markets
items.verse: Do not be deceived! Fornicators, idolaters, adulterers, effeminate ones, those who lie with men, thieves, the greedy, drunkards, revilers, robbers—none of these will inherit the kingdom of God.

items.text: Against the thoughts that establish in our heart fornication, which the Lord sees as having been committed
items.verse: We must not indulge in fornication as some of them did, and twenty-three thousand fell in a single day.

items.text: Against the unclean thoughts that sometimes hand us over to visions of the night and at other times during the day begin to depict a vision of images in our intellect
items.verse: Be sure of this, that no fornicator or impure person, or one who is greedy (that is, an idolater), has any inheritance in the kingdom of Christ and of God.

items.text: Against the thought that supposes that temptations come upon human beings from God
items.verse: No one, when tempted, should say, “I am being tempted by God”; for God cannot be tempted by evil and he himself tempts no one. But one is tempted by one’s own desire.

items.text: Against the soul that does not know that it is due to the desires that every kind of temptation from the demons comes upon it
items.verse: Those conflicts and disputes among you, where do they come from? Do they not come from your desires that are at war within you?

items.text: Against the soul’s thought that does not endure the touch of the demon that suddenly fell between the thighs, moved in them from below, and set [them] on fire
items.verse: Beloved, do not be surprised at the fiery ordeal that is taking place among you to test you, as though something strange were happening to you. But rejoice insofar as you are sharing Christ’s sufferings, so that you may also be glad and shout for joy when his glory is revealed.

items.text: Against the soul’s thought that succumbs to distress and sadness and supposes that it is the only one that is tempted so severely
items.verse: Discipline yourselves, keep watch. Like a roaring lion your adversary the devil prowls around, looking for someone to devour. Resist him, steadfast in your faith, for you know that your brothers in all the world are undergoing the same kinds of suffering.

items.text: Against the thought that threatened me and said, “You are going to suffer from the demons unspeakable evils,” which I do not want to set down in writing, lest I hinder the zeal of those who are contending, cast terror into those who have just now withdrawn from the world, and scandalize the inexperienced persons who are in the world; for truly I have seen the demonsperform many unspeakable acts, things that perhaps it is not lawful to say to most people; for I have been seized by great astonishment over the patience of the holy angels, how they have not burned or consumed them with the flame of the unquenchable fire
items.verse: The Lord knows how to rescue the godly from trial, and to keep the unrighteous under punishment until the day of judgment.

title:
THIRD BOOK
Concerning Love of Money

items.text: Against the demon that advised me in my thinking, “In a dream I will entice one of your relatives or one of the rich people to send you gold”
items.verse: I stretch out my hand to the most high God, who made heaven and earth, if from a string to a shoe-latchet I take from all that is yours.

items.text: Against the thought that shows me bitter poverty and the evils that arise from it and suggests to me that on the day of need I will not find a helper
items.verse: If the Lord God will be with me, and guard me on this way on which I am going, and give me bread to eat and clothes to wear, and return me safely to the house of my father, then shall the Lord be for me as God, and this stone, which I have set up as a pillar, shall be for me God’s house.

items.text: Against the thought of love of money that made us revile our parents because they did not give usany of their property
items.verse: The one who reviles his father or his mother shall surely die.

items.text: Against the thought that, on account of love of money, leads us to afflict with the burden of many labors a brother who has recently become a disciple
items.verse: You shall not afflict the proselyte, for you know the soul of the proselyte. For you yourselves were proselytes in the land of Egypt.

items.text: Against the thought of love of money that withheld compassion from a brother who asked out of his needand that advised us to store up for ourselves alone
items.verse: You shall love your neighbor as yourself. I am the Lord.

items.text: Against the thought of love of money that makes us hinder a brother from reading the Scriptures or learning a teaching and that incites us, for the sake of temporary gain, to push him into toil and labor
items.verse: Let no person afflict his neighbor, and you shall fear the Lord your God. For it is I who am the Lord your God.

items.text: Against the thought of love of money that neglects someone who has been sick with a long illness and is greatly afflicted by poverty
items.verse: If your brother who is with you becomes poor and cannot support himself, you shall help him as a stranger and sojourner, and your brother shall live with you.

items.text: Against the thought that demanded more manual labor from a brother than he is capable of
items.verse: Each shall not oppress his brother in labors.

items.text: Against the thought that did not permit us to give to a needy brother who asked to borrow something from us
items.verse: You shall not close your hand to your brother who is in need. You shall open your hands to him and lend him as much as he needs.

items.text: Against the thought that seeks to keep resources for itself and does not want to give relief to one of the brothers from them
items.verse: Cursed shall be your barns and your reserves. Cursed shall be the offspring of your belly and the fruits of your land.

items.text: Against the thought that would increase wealth rather than poverty
items.verse: Is not the gleaning of Ephraim better than the vintage of Abiezer?

items.text: Against the soul’s thought that shows mercy to the poor, but immediately changes its mind and regrets the money that it spent on them
items.verse: Let our hearts be perfect toward the Lord our God, to walk also reverently in his ordinances, and to keep his commandments as this very day.

items.text: Against the soul that wants to attain the death of Jesus while retaining some wealth and forgets how Elisha the prophet, when he renounced the world, divested himself of all that he had
items.verse: And he departed from there and found Elisha the son of Shaphat, and he was plowing with oxen; there were twelve yoke of oxen before him, and he was with the twelfth. And he passed by him and cast his mantle upon him. And Elisha left the cattle and ran after Elijah and said, “I will kiss my father, and then I will follow you.” And Elijah said, “Go back, for I have done [something] for you.” And he returned from following him, and took the yoke of oxen, and slew them and boiled them with the instruments of the oxen, and gave them to the people, and they ate. And he arose and went after Elijah and ministered to him.

items.text: Against the soul that is stingy with money and with everything else stored up for it and is unwilling to spend from it on brothers who come
items.verse: And Elisha said to his slave, “Set on the great pot, and boil soup for the sons of the prophets.”

items.text: Against the soul that has accepted gold that was sent for the business of the brothers and yearns to spend it according to the choice of its own desires, forgetting Gehazi’s leprosy—let those reading consider how Elisha the prophet revealed that the thought of love of money is the first of the evil passions, after which follow the rest of the accompanying concepts, from which is generated an extended period of thoughts that hinder the intellect with evil matters and make it leprous
items.verse: And Elisha said to him, “Where are you coming from, Gehazi?” And Gehazi said, “Your servant did not go here or there.” But Elisha said to him, “Did not my heart go with you when the man came back from his chariot to meet you? And now you accepted silver, and now you have accepted clothing, olive orchards, vineyards, sheep, oxen, and male and female slaves. And Naaman’s leprosy shall cleave also to you and to your offspring forever.” And he went out from his presence leprous, like snow.

items.text: To the Lord concerning the thought of love of money that reminded me by suggesting, “Look, you have given up your parents’ inheritance”
items.verse: The Lord is the share of my inheritance and of my cup.

items.text: Against the thoughts that taunt us because our parents have forsaken us and will not send us gold to meet our need
items.verse: For my father and my mother have forsaken me, but the Lord has received me.

items.text: Against the thoughts that suggest to us, “Look, your brothers in the world are rich and honored by everyone because of their wealth”
items.verse: My soul shall be honored in the Lord; let the meek hear and rejoice.

items.text: Against the soul that does not understand that we will be condemned along with Satan unless we rightly administer the possessions that we have been given by God
items.verse: The sinner watches the righteous person and seeks to kill him. But the Lord will not leave him in his hands, nor will he condemn him when he is judged.

items.text: Against the soul that clings to the world, loves temporal things, and wants the house and property of its parents
items.verse: Listen, daughter, and see, and incline your ear: forget your people and your father’s house. For the King has desired your beauty.

items.text: Against the thoughts that meditate upon riches and give no heed to the consuming pain of wealth
items.verse: If wealth should increase, do not set your heart upon it.

items.text: Against the thought that shows us our parents’ splendid house and renders our little cell odious in our eyes
items.verse: I would rather be a castoff in the house of God than dwell in the tents of sinners.

items.text: Against the thought that needs money on the pretext of required possessions and has severed its hope from God’s grace
items.verse: The Lord will not withhold good things from those who walk in innocence.

items.text: To the Lord concerning the thought of love of money that persists in us and suggests to our intellect either the remembrance of money that we have renounced, or the effort that we are making to acquire things that at present cannot be seen, or the preservation and safekeeping of the things we have now
Against the thoughts of love of money that depict in me hospitality, compel my soul to take advantage of other people, and incite it to render judgment for the sake of temporal goods
items.verse: The proud have hidden a snare for me, and they have stretched out ropes as snares for my feet; they set a stumbling block for me near the path.

items.text: Against the thought of love of money that prophesies to us that we are going to live in bitter poverty for a long time
items.verse: A human being is like vanity; his days pass by as a shadow.

items.text: Against the soul that because of the passion of love of money offers scarcely anything for mercy
items.verse: Let not mercy and faith forsake you, but bind them about your neck, and you will find favor. Provide good things before the Lord and human beings.

items.text: Against the thought of love of money that prevents us from performing acts of beneficence and suggests to us poverty and bodily infirmity [as excuses]
items.verse: Do not refrain from doing good to the poor whenever it is in your power to help. Do not say, “Come back another time, and tomorrow I will give.”

items.text: Against the thought of love of money that, on account of the desire for wealth, drove us to perform manual labor night and day, and so deprived us of reading the Holy Scriptures and prevented us from visiting and ministering to the sick
items.verse: Wealth does not profit on the day of wrath, but righteousness delivers from death.

items.text: Against the thought that oppresses us because we are spending our money too freely
items.verse: A man’s own wealth is his life’s ransom, but a poor person is not threatened.

items.text: Against the thought that, by means of restraint of compassion, prefers money to God’s wisdom
items.verse: Wisdom’s brood is choicer than gold, prudence’s brood choicer than silver.

items.text: Against the thought of love of money that seeks relaxation and glory from riches
items.verse: A good name is better than a lot of wealth, and good favor surpasses silver and gold.

items.text: Against the intellect that is set free from the thoughts of love of money through almsgiving, but through sorrow and murmuring is once again ensnared in them—these circumstances show that the soul does not discern the passions caused by the thoughts nor does it recognize [that they are] fetters for the rational nature that strives for knowledge of God
items.verse: God loves a cheerful and generous man, but he shall complete what is lacking of his works.

items.text: Against the thoughts that remind us of home and property and of the way of life associated with them
items.verse: “Vanity of vanities,” said the Preacher, “vanity of vanities: all is vanity!.”

items.text: Against the thought of love of money that both wants to preserve those things that are stored within and wants to collect additional things from without, on the pretexts of refreshment of the brothers and acquisitions of the Holy Scriptures
items.verse: The one who loves silver will not be satisfied with silver, and who has been content with gain in its abundance? This is also vanity.

items.text: Against the thought that depicted before our eyes the loss of the wealth or property that was of great bodily refreshment to Job
items.verse: The Lord gave, and the Lord took away, as it seemed good to the Lord.

items.text: Against the thought of love of money that advised us to stockpile food and clothing and not to give them to the brothers who need them
items.verse: Break your bread for the hungry person, and bring the poor without shelter into your house. If you see a naked person, clothe him, and do not overlook relatives of your own seed.

items.text: Against the soul that does not yield to mercy when it sees the brothers’ poverty
items.verse: Blessed are the merciful, for they will receive mercy.

items.text: Against the soul that wants, because of money or property that has been taken from it, to file a lawsuit, and does not recognize that it will not be set free from the fetters of the thoughts caused by what has been taken from it unless in love it offers its cloak as well
items.verse: And if anyone wants to sue you and take your coat, give your cloak as well.

items.text: Against the thought that prevented us from lending to a brother on the pretext that he cannot repay
items.verse: Give to everyone who begs from you, and do not refuse anyone who wants to borrow from you.

items.text: Against the inner thoughts that want to acquire riches and to consume the intellect with anxiety about them
items.verse: Do not store up for yourselves treasures on earth, where moth and rust consume and where thieves break in and steal.

items.text: Against the demon that said to us, “Property can, when a person acquires riches, serve the Lord”
items.verse: No one can serve two masters; for a slave will either hate the one and love the other, or be devoted to the one and despise the other. You cannot serve God and wealth.

items.text: Against the soul that in a time of distress wants its need to be filled by others, but does not want to refresh others who are afflicted and in want
items.verse: In everything do to others as you would have them do to you; for this is the law and the prophets.

items.text: Against the thought that did not permit us to share our wealth when a noble occasion was depicted before our eyes
items.verse: How hard it will be for those who have wealth to enter the kingdom of God!

items.text: Against the intellect that performed acts of righteousness but before which was depicted an image of fraud, murmuring, and sullen faces, things alien to love of practicing the commandments; and that does not want to be troubled by such passions on account of the holy knowledge that comes to the intellect when it has been stripped of the foul passions
items.verse: The compassionate, in cheerfulness. Let love be genuine.

items.text: Against the thought of love of money that called blessed our corporeal brothers and our kinfolk who are in the world because they possess visible wealth
items.verse: For what can be seen is temporary, but what cannot be seen is eternal.

items.text: Against the thought that is sparing in what it gives to the poor—for giving alms sets the intellect free from thoughts, while regretting what one has given binds the intellect to the thoughts that impede it and that damage its ability to receive the knowledge of God
items.verse: The point is this: the one who sows sparingly will also reap sparingly, and the one who sows bountifully will also reap bountifully.

items.text: Against the thoughts of love of money that corrupt kindness to the brothers
items.verse: And be kind to one another, tenderhearted, forgiving one another, as God in Christ has forgiven you.

items.text: Against the thought that seeks to store up possessions for itself alone
items.verse: Let each of you look not to your own interests, but to the interests of others.

items.text: Against the thought that presents to us the advantage of possessions and displays to us past wealth that would be able to support many brothers
items.verse: Yet whatever gains I had, these I have come to regard as loss because of Christ. More than that, I regard everything as loss because of the surpassing value of knowing Christ Jesus my Lord. For his sake I have suffered the loss of all things, and I regard them as rubbish, in order that I may gain Christ.

items.text: Against the thoughts that reconcile us to greed and that do not see the idolatry that is born from it
items.verse: Put to death, therefore, whatever in you is earthly: fornication, impurity, passion, evil desire, and greed, which is idolatry. On account of these the wrath of God is coming on those who are disobedient.

items.text: Against the thoughts that seek to collect for our need more than what we need and that desire to acquire wealth
items.verse: Keep your lives free from the love of money, and be content with what you have; for he has said, “I will never leave you or forsake you.”

items.text: Against the soul that seeks more than food and clothing and does not remember that it entered the world bare and it will leave it naked
items.verse: For we brought nothing into the world, so that we can take nothing out of it; but if we have food and clothing, we will be content with these.

items.text: Against the thought of love of money that said that nothing evil attaches to love of money, but rather great refreshment for the brothers and for strangers [attaches to it]
items.verse: For the love of money is a root of all kinds of evil, and in their eagerness to be rich some have wandered away from the faith and pierced themselves with many pains.

items.text: Against the thought that seeks, on the pretext that profit will fill its need, to be entangled in the affairs of the world
items.verse: No one serving in the army gets entangled in everyday affairs; the soldier’s aim is to please the enlisting officer. And in the case of an athlete, no one is crowned without competing according to the rules.

items.text: Against the thought that anxiously serves in business affairs on the pretext that the money has run out, and now there is nothing left of it, and it cannot be regained
items.verse: Whoever serves must do so with the strength that God supplies, so that God may be glorified in all things through Jesus Christ.

items.text: Against the thought of love of money that did not want to give alms to the brothers on the pretext that “they are not in need” and so in action renounced God’s love
items.verse: How does God’s love abide in anyone who has the world’s goods and sees a brother in need and yet refuses help?

items.text: Against the thoughts that make us confess in word that we love the brothers, while in action we will renounce them because of love of money
items.verse: Little children, let us love, not in word or speech, but in truth and action. Blessed is our Lord, God, and Savior, Jesus Christ, who has given us the victory over the demon of love of money, so that we might defeat it! Amen. 99

title:
FOURTH BOOK
Concerning the Thoughts of the
Demon of Sadness

items.text: Against the soul that, due to the sadness that comes upon it, thinks that the Lord has not heard its groaning
items.verse: The children of Israel groaned because of their tasks, and cried, and their cry because of their tasks went up to God. And God heard their groanings.

items.text: Against the thoughts that suppose that the Lord does not see our affliction that comes from the demons
items.verse: And the Lord said to Moses, “I have surely seen the affliction of my people that is in Egypt, and I have heard their cry caused by their taskmasters, for I know their hardship, and I have come down to deliver them out of the hand of the Egyptians.”

items.text: Against the soul that does not realize that temptations quickly multiply when it has started to investigate spiritually the living words of God and it has become diligent about God’s commandments
items.verse: Moses turned to the Lord and said, “I pray, Lord, why have you afflicted this people? And why did you send me? For from the time when I went to Pharaoh to speak in your name, he has afflicted this people, and you have not delivered your people.”

items.text: Against the thoughts that do not expect to receive help from God and which cast down the soul through sadness
items.verse: Speak to the children of Israel, saying, “I am the Lord, and I will lead you out from the tyranny of the Egyptians, and I will deliver you from slavery, and I will ransom you with a raised arm and a great judgment. I will take you to myself as my people, and I will be your God.”

items.text: Against the soul that is not convinced that those who have renounced the world only recently will not fall into the hands of the wretched demons and do not fight open attacks through visions or sensation, lest they be alarmed by their [the demons’] terrors and return to the world
items.verse: When Pharaoh sent the people out, God did not lead them by the way of the Philistines, although it was near, for God said, “lest at any time the people repent when they see war and return to Egypt.”

items.text: Against the thoughts that say to us, “The demons do not know that the Lord makes war on our behalf ”
items.verse: The Egyptians said, “Let us flee from before Israel, for the Lord makes war on their behalf against the Egyptians.”

items.text: Against the soul that does not know why the demons plot against us
items.verse: The enemy said, “I will pursue, I will overtake, I will divide the spoils. I will satisfy my soul, I will destroy with my sword, my hand shall rule.”

items.text: To the Lord concerning the thoughts that frighten us by saying, “At night demons will come and fall upon you”
items.verse: Let fear and trembling fall upon them. By the greatness of your arm let them become as stone, until your people pass over, Lord, until your people pass over, which you purchased.

items.text: Against the thoughts of terror that come upon us because the angel who assists us is not visible
items.verse: With a secret hand the Lord wages war against Amalek from generations to generations.

items.text: Against the soul that is afraid, as if God’s angels do not watch over it
items.verse: And look, I am sending my angel before you, so that it might keep watch over you along the way, so that it might lead you into the land that I have prepared for you.

items.text: Against the soul that is saddened by the tumult of the night and, because of terror, supposes that it will remain in its commotion forever
items.verse: I will give peace in your land,... and you will pursue your enemies, and they will fall before you in slaughter.

items.text: Against the human thoughts that consider us and say, “It is of no use for you to fight against the demons”
items.verse: And I said to you, “Do not fear, and do not be afraid of them. The Lord your God who goes before you will himself fight alongside you against them.”

items.text: Against the soul that has been frightened by the voice of a demon that hissed at it suddenly in the air
items.verse: Begin to inherit it; engage in war with him. In this day I will begin to put the terror and fear of you upon all the nations that are under heaven, who will be troubled when they have heard your name and will be in anguish before you.

items.text: Against the human thoughts that are terrified by the vision of a demon whose eyes flash like fire
items.verse: Do not be afraid of them. The Lord your God who goes before you will himself fight alongside you against them.

items.text: To the Lord concerning the soul that remained undisturbed when suddenly demons fell upon the body with noise and tumult
items.verse: Lord, Lord, you have begun to show to your servant your strength, your power, your mighty hand, and your high arm, for what god is there in heaven or on earth who will do as you have done and according to your might?

items.text: Against the soul that is frightened and scared by the demons that appear to it and supposes that the Lord has abandoned it
items.verse: The Lord your God will not abandon you, nor will he destroy you; he will not forget the covenant of your fathers, which the Lord swore to them.

items.text: Against the soul that wants to know the reason for these trials
items.verse: ... so that he might afflict you and test you and treat you well at the end of your days.

items.text: Against the human thoughts that are frightened by the vision of demons that come to us at night twisted like snakes on one’s back and side
items.verse: Do not let your heart become faint; do not be afraid; do not tremble, and do not turn away from them, for it is the Lord your God who advances with you, to wage war with you against your enemies so as to rescue you.

items.text: Against the soul that is saddened and frightened by the demons that come upon it suddenly at night
items.verse: Be courageous and strong; do not fear or be cowardly; do not be afraid before them. For it is the Lord your God who advances with you and among you, who will not forsake you or abandon you.

items.text: Against the soul that wants, through its withdrawal from the world, to grow strong in the fear of God, but is hindered by the fear that comes from the demons
items.verse: Be strong and courageous; do not be cowardly or afraid. For the Lord your God is with you wherever you may go.

items.text: Against the thoughts that hesitate to undertake the life of fear of God out of fear of the frightening visions and lamps of fire that fly through the air
items.verse: Do not be afraid of them, and do not be cowardly... for thus the Lord will do to all your enemies against whom you wage war.

items.text: Against the soul that succumbs to sadness and therefore is frightened by visions of the night
items.verse: Wake up, wake up, Deborah! Wake up, wake up, and sing a song! Get up, Barak, and lead your captivity captive, son of Abinoam!

items.text: Against the soulthat does not know that the melody that accompanies the Psalms alters the condition of the body and drives away the demon that touches it on the back, chills its sinews, and troubles all its members
items.verse: And it happened that when the evil spirit was upon Saul, David took his harp and played with his hand, and Saul was refreshed, and it was good with him, and the evil spirit departed from him.

items.text: Against the demon that appears carrying a sword—we should, as in a hostile manner, answer back with a phrase, just as our blessed father Abba Macarius answered it when he saw it carrying a sword and coming to attack him when he had traveled to see the paradise that Jannes and Jambres made
items.verse: You come to me with a sword and a spear and a shield, but I come to you in the name of the Lord God of hosts.

items.text: Against the demons that make a commotion in the air and then make us listen to their voices
items.verse: Not with a sword or spear does the Lord deliver, for the battle belongs to the Lord, and the Lord will deliver you into our hands.

items.text: Against the demon that threatens me with curses and said, “I will make you an object of laughter and reproach among all the monks because you have investigated and made known all the kinds of all the unclean thoughts”
items.verse: That’s enough! Let not the humpbacked one boast like the one that is upright!

items.text: Against the soul that is frightened by the demons that appear suddenly in the air
items.verse: Do not be afraid, for those that are with us outnumber those that are with them.

items.text: Against the soul that does not believe that the air is filled with holy angels that help us and are not visible to the demons
items.verse: Elisha prayed and said, “Lord, open the eyes of the servant, and let him see.” And the Lord opened his eyes, and he saw. And look, the mountain was filled with horses, and there were chariots of fire encircling Elisha.

items.text: Against the thought that cast me into fear and trembling on the pretext that demons are coming and fighting with me
items.verse: The one who dwells in the heavens will laugh them to scorn, and the Lord will mock them. Then he will speak to them in his anger, and in his fury he will trouble them.

items.text: To the Lord concerning the disordered and foul visions that appear to us at night
items.verse: Have mercy upon me, Lord, for I am weak; heal me, Lord, for my bones are troubled. My soul is greatly troubled, and as for you, Lord, how long? Return, Lord, and deliver my soul; save me for your mercy’s sake.

items.text: Against the thoughts that advise us to flee from before the demons’ evil and not to oppose them valiantly in the contest
items.verse: In the Lord I have placed my trust. How will you say to my soul, “Flee to the mountains as a sparrow”?

items.text: To the Lord concerning the expectation that demons are about to come upon us at night
items.verse: Rise up, Lord, and prevent them, and cast them down. Deliver my soul from the ungodly, your sword from the enemies of your hand.

items.text: Against the soul that is disturbed by the tumultuous sounds and commotion of the demons
items.verse: Some glory in chariots and some in horses, but we will glory in the name of the Lord our God. They are overthrown and fallen, but we have arisen and have been set upright.

items.text: Against the demons that touch our bodies at night and like scorpions strike our limbs
items.verse: The Lord is my light and my savior; whom shall I fear? The Lord is the defender of my life; of whom shall I be afraid?

items.text: Against the demons that suddenly appear to us out of the air like Ethiopians
items.verse: If an army arrays itself against me, my heart shall not fear; if war arises against me, in this I have hope.

items.text: To the Lord concerning the demon of sadness that approached me and that alone [among the demons] did not create a desire, but whose entire work was in the head and in the back; having introduced sadness with thoughts, it then no longer required thoughts, but cast the soul into great and unnecessary distress
items.verse: You are my refuge from the affliction that surrounds me, my joy, to deliver me from those that encircle me.

items.text: To the Lord concerning the demons that fall upon the skin of the body, put branding marks in it as if made by fire, and make visible marks in it as if made by a cupping-glass—things that I have seen many times with my own eyes and at which I have marveled
items.verse: Judge, Lord, those who do me injustice; make war against those who make war against me. Take hold of a shield and buckler, and rise up for my help. Bring forth a sword, and stop the way against those that persecute me. Say to my soul, “I am your salvation.”

items.text: To the Lord concerning the demon of sadness that alters the intellect and impresses it with a single concept that is filled with severe grief—this is an indication of great madness
items.verse: Deliver my soul from their wickedness, my only-begotten one from the lions.

items.text: Against the thought that threatens me and said, “Look, at night demons will come, carrying swords”
items.verse: Let their sword enter into their own heart, and let their bows be broken.

items.text: Against the thought that prophesies to me concerning the scourge that comes from demons
items.verse: For I am ready for scourges, and my grief is continually before me.

items.text: Against the soul that, in the time of sadness, wants to find in prayer spiritual words
items.verse: Do not forsake me, Lord; my God, do not depart from me. Come near to help me, Lord of my salvation.

items.text: To the Lord concerning the demons that burned the body’s sinews
items.verse: Take from me your scourges; from the strength of your hand I have fainted.

items.text: Against the soul concerning the thought of sadness that depicted before our eyes our father’s old age, our mother’s lack of strength, and the sorrow of our relatives, who are not comforted
items.verse: His words are smoother than oil, but they are darts.

items.text: To the Lord concerning the demon that in my intellect threatens me with madness and mental illness, to the shame of me and of those who seek the Lord through the monastic life
items.verse: Do not let those who wait on you, Lord of hosts, be ashamed on my account. Do not let those who seek you, God of Israel, be embarrassed because of me.

items.text: Against the soul that does not understand what the leaders of the demons say about persons who have been “abandoned by the Lord”
items.verse: For my enemies have spoken against me, and those that would possess my soul have taken counsel together, saying, “God has abandoned him. Pursue him and seize him, for he has no deliverer.”

items.text: To the Lord concerning the serpents that appear flying in the air and also make themselves come out of the walls—we should say what the ancient Egyptian, the blessed Macarius, opened his mouth and said
items.verse: Do not hand over to the beasts a soul that confesses you.

items.text: Against the soul that is not convinced that the filthy demons talk to one another about us
items.verse: They have said, “Come, and let us destroy them out of the nation, and let the name of Israel no longer be remembered.”

items.text: Against the demons that gradually begin to imitate obscene images and to appear out of the air—we should answer with a phrase, as also the righteous blessed Antony answered and said
items.verse: The Lord is my helper, and I shall look upon my enemies.

items.text: Against the demon that burst into flame like a fire and then dissolved again into smoke
items.verse: The snare has been broken, and we have been delivered. Our help is in the name of the Lord, who made heaven and earth.

items.text: To the Lord concerning the demon that threatens to burn me with a flaming fire
items.verse: Coals will fall upon them, and you will cast them down into fire; in hardships they will not bear up.

items.text: Against the thought that said to me, “The path that leads to knowledge of Jesus Christ is full of great danger and much affliction”
items.verse: The timid person makes excuses and says, “There is a lion in the paths and murderers in the streets.”

items.text: Against the soul that does not know that Satan cannot approach even cattle without God’s command
items.verse: You have blessed the works of his hand, and you have made his cattle numerous upon the land. But stretch out your hand, and touch all that he has, and [see] whether truly he will bless you to your face.

items.text: Against the soul that does not understand that, after the trials that it has through thoughts, Satan sets to work and requests of God that he be given authority over the body
items.verse: The devil answered and said to the Lord, “Skin for skin, as much as a person has he will give as a ransom for his soul. No, rather, stretch out your hand, and touch his bones and his flesh, and [see] whether truly he will bless you to your face.”

items.text: Against the thoughts that frighten us by prophesying to us and saying, “Look, at night demons will come like stars and appear in the cell and burn your eyes and face”—it is expedient for us at that moment of trial to kneel, to persist in prayer, to turn away our face, and not to look when they are trying to disturb us
items.verse: Let the stars of that night be darkened; let [that night] remain dark and not come into light, and let it not see the morning star rise.

items.text: Against the thought that prophesies to me and said, “Death will come to you from the demons”
items.verse: For if a human being should die, will he live again after having completed the days of his life?

items.text: Against the evil spirit that opposes my soul, introduces and displays to me sins of the past, and tries to cast sadness into it [my soul]
items.verse: Do not rejoice over me, my enemy, because I have fallen. I shall rise up, for if I sit in darkness, the Lord serves as a light for me.

items.text: Against the soul that does not valiantly withstand the demon that at the time of prayer suddenly comes, lands on the shouldersand neck, scratches the ears, and punches the nose
items.verse: The Lord is kind to those who wait upon him on the day of affliction, knowing those who show him reverence.

items.text: Against the soul that wants to learn what is to happen to the demons on the day of judgment and what is the generation of torment to which they are to be handed over—concerning this torment the prophet, prophesying mystically, narrated and said
items.verse: And this is the overthrow with which the Lord will strike all the nations that fought against Jerusalem: their flesh will rot away while they are standing on their feet, and their eyes will melt out of their sockets, and their tongue will rot away in their mouth.

items.text: Against the demons that suddenly emitted fire and disturbed with alarming sounds—because they cast the soul into a stupor, we should not let it [the soul] fall into their terror, but we should say what our holy father Macarius also answered against them and said
items.verse: Know, you nations, and be conquered; listen, even to the end of the earth. Having become strong, be conquered. For even if you become strong again, you will be conquered again. And whatever counsel you should take, the Lord will bring it to naught; and whatever word you speak, it shall not endure, for God is with us.

items.text: Against the thoughts that come to us because of the weakness that the demons create in us
items.verse: I do not disobey, nor do I dispute. I gave my back to scourges and my cheek to blows. I did not turn my face away from the shame of spitting, but the Lord God was my helper.

items.text: Against the soul’s thought that saddens it because of the contempt that it receives when friends and relatives reproach it for not having distributed to them from its wealth, and in turn it receives no consolation from them
items.verse: Do not fear the reproach of human beings, and do not be overcome by their contempt.

items.text: Against the soul that does not understand that empty thoughts give birth within it to fear and trembling, and they obscure the holy light that confidence gives to the intellect
items.verse: Abstain from injustice, and you will not be afraid, and trembling will not come near to you.

items.text: Against the soul that is frightened by the flashes of lightning that happen on the walls
items.verse: Do not be afraid before them, for I am with you to rescue you, says the Lord.
